 PROJECT AT A GLANCE 

 

  

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
supplementary  loan  to  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  for  the  CAREC  Regional  Road  Corridor 
Improvement Project. 
 

II. 

THE APPROVED PROJECT 

A. 

Project Rationale 

2. 
The  road  network  is  the  backbone  of  the  Kyrgyz  Republic's  agriculture  industry,  which 
accounts  for  over  30%  of  gross  domestic  product  and  employs  more  than  50%  of  the 
population.  It  also  carries  more  than  half  the  imports  and  exports  from  neighboring  countries, 
and is essential for the growing tourism industry. The economy of the Kyrgyz Republic depends 
heavily  on  road  links  to  neighboring  countries  and  through  them  to  the  major  aviation  and 
marine  gateways,  particularly  in  South  Asia.  Parts  of  these  links  are  also  vital  for  connecting 
different  parts  of  the  country  and  thereby  reducing  provincial  disparities.  The  government’s 
current  goal  is  to  upgrade  all  international  and  strategic  roads  to  a  uniform  standard,  but  the 
emphasis will switch to local roads in the future.1   
 
Road development, which began in the mid-1990s, has accelerated in recent years, and 
3. 
the government is now paying more attention to road pavement preservation and sustainability. 
By  2009,  it  had  increased  routine  road  maintenance  and  small  works  expenditure  to  Som1.6 
billion (approximately $40 million)—about seven times the expenditure in 2005. Multilateral and 
bilateral development partners have financed the bulk of road rehabilitation and reconstruction 
works.  The  CAREC  Regional  Road  Corridor  Improvement  Project,2 approved  by  the  Board  of 
Directors of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on 24 October 20073 (the approved project), is 
one  in  a  series  of  projects  financed  by  ADB  in  support  of  the  government's  efforts  to  make 
roads safe, efficient, and available year-round.  
 
4. 
The approved project's main component is the improvement of the road from Sary Tash 
to  Karamik  (at  the  Kyrgyz  Republic–Tajikistan  border).  This  road  is  part  of  the  Central  Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation4 (CAREC) corridors 3 and 5, which extend from Afghanistan to 
the Russian Federation and the People's Republic of China (PRC) respectively. Improvements 
to  some  sections  of  corridors  3  and  5,  particularly  the  road  between  Karamik  and  Dushanbe, 
are  also  financed  by  ADB.  Under  the  approved  project,  the  customs  facilities  at  the  Karamik 
border post will be improved and the government's road maintenance unit and its practices will 
be reformed. 
 
B. 

Objectives and Scope 

5. 
The principal objectives of the approved project are to reduce transport costs and foster 
regional cooperation among the Kyrgyz Republic, the PRC, Tajikistan, and other Central Asian

countries. The road will improve access to regional markets and social services for people living 
along the corridor. 
 
6. 
The  approved  project  will  have  two  physical  and  two  nonphysical  outputs.  The  main 
physical output is an improved 142-kilometer (km) road connecting Karamik and Sary Tash (km 
350–km 492). The improvements will include rehabilitating an existing 30 km asphalt concrete 
surfaced section (km 462–km 492) and reconstruction of the remaining existing gravel- surfaced 
road, river protection works, improvement of drainage systems, and road safety measures. The 
approved  project  will  also  replace  deteriorated  bridges,  repair  12  bridges,  and  build  four  new 
bridges.  All  the  civil  works  have  been  designed  to  comply  with  national  highway  design 
standards.  The  other  output  is  a  new  passenger  and  vehicle  inspection  area  with  modern 
buildings, equipment, and traffic channels at the border post in Karamik.5 
 
7. 
The  nonphysical  outputs  are:  (i)  a  tri-nation  cross-border  agreement  among  the  PRC, 
the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  and  Tajikistan,  to  allow  easy  movement  of  people  and  goods  across 
borders;6 and  (ii)  better  road  maintenance  by  procuring  works  from  the  private  sector  under 
performance-based contracts.

D. 

Status of and Progress in Project Implementation 

10. 
Government  and  ADB  review  missions  have  visited  the  civil  works  site;  reviewed 
progress reports, financial audit reports, and the operations of the project implementation unit, 
and found that the approved project is in compliance with the financial covenants and that the 
civil works meet all technical and safeguard requirements. The civil works, which commenced 
operations  on  1  December  2008,  were  50%  completed  at  the  end  of  March  2010  (compared 
with the anticipated 33%), and the supervision consultant has certified that the completed work 
meets  all  standards  and  specifications.7 Disbursements  amounted  to  about  40%  of  the  civil 
works allocation, and 51% of total financing. 
 
11. 
However,  the  road  maintenance  component  has  progressed  more  slowly  than  the  civil 
works. The intent of this component is twofold: (i) to help restructure the road maintenance unit 
of  the  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Communications  (MOTC),  and  (ii)  to  improve  maintenance 
effectiveness  by  outsourcing  the  works  by  2013.  The  government  has  demonstrated  its 
commitment to this end by increasing maintenance funding.8 
  
12. 
Progress  with  the  cross-border  agreement  and  the  customs  facility  improvement 
component has also been slow. The government is committed to taking the action required to 
complete  the  cross-border  agreement.  However,  its  completion  and  implementation  before  
31 December 2010, as required under the financial covenants, will depend on Tajikistan and the 
PRC  signing  the  agreement.  The  government  will  also  ensure  that  the  customs  facility 
improvements  are  expedited  and  completed  on  time.  The  designs  of  the  border  infrastructure 
have been completed and the government is expected to procure the works at the end of 2010. 
The  road  works  contractor  is  scheduled  to  complete  paving  the  inspection  area  and  traffic 
channels in 2011.   
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED SUPPLEMENTARY LOAN 

A. 

Proposed Changes 

13.

component of the approved project, i.e., paving the entire length of 136 km (instead of only 30 
km)  with  two  layers  (4  centimeters  [cm]  and  6  cm  respectively)  of  asphalt  concrete.  The  two 
layers  will  be  designed  to  standards  and  specifications  required  to  achieve  an  international 
roughness  index  not  exceeding  3.5  and  a  service  life  of  20  years  on  the  entire  road.  The

B. 

Impact on the Project 

14. 
The proposed changes will increase the approved project's overall impact because it will 
reduce transport costs further. The current travel time of 13 hours between Dushanbe and the 
Kyrgyz Republic–PRC border at Irkeshtam will be more than halved. The changes will require 
civil works and consulting services to continue for about 18 months beyond the current contract 
end date of 21 May 2011 (i.e., until  1 November 2012). The milestones of some other activities, 
outcomes, and outputs will be postponed because of their start-up delays—not because of the 
proposed  changes.  However,  the  project  completion  date  of  31  March  2013  will  remain 
unchanged. The revised project design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
C. 

Rationale 

Although  the  feasibility  study9 for  the  approved  project  concluded  that  a  5  cm  layer  of 
15. 
asphalt  concrete  would  be  needed  on  the  entire  road  to  support  the  estimated  future  traffic,10 
ADB financing for the road sector in the approved project was only sufficient to pave 30 km of 
the  136  km  road.  However,  the  road  network  in  southeast  Kyrgyz  Republic11 and  Tajikistan  is 
currently  being  improved  with  ADB  assistance  with  10–11  cm,  two-layer  asphalt  concrete 
surfacing. ADB recently provided supplementary financing12 to Tajikistan to pave road sections 
between Karamik and Nimich, which were originally designed to have gravel surfacing.   
 
Current  traffic  volumes  in  other  major  road  links  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  that  were 
16. 
improved between 2004 and 2009 are more than twice the forecasts. Heavy vehicles constitute 
a larger portion of the traffic than anticipated. The likelihood of similar increases in traffic volume 
and composition on the Sary Tash–Karamik road is high. This and the findings of the feasibility 
study  fully  support  the  government's  proposal  to  pave  the  entire  road.  The  long-term 
serviceability and life-cycle cost advantages further support the government’s proposal to use a 
10 cm two-layer asphalt concrete surfacing instead of a single 5 cm layer surfacing.   
 
The  government  has  confirmed,  and  the  project  team  has  determined,  that  the  project 
17. 
continues  to  be  a  priority  in  its  development  strategy.  The  transport  sector  is  performing  well 
and the percentage of primary network roads in good condition and the level of network usage 
have  improved  since  2005.  Reforms,  in  line  with  the  financial  covenants  of  the  approved 
project,  have  also  contributed  to  these  improvements.  Overall,  the  proposed  supplementary 
financing  complies  with  the  eligibility  criteria  set  out  in  ADB's  Policy  on  Supplementary 
Financing.13 It  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  country  operations  business  plan,  2009–2011,14 the

D. 

Safeguards 

18. 
There  will  be  no  land  acquisition,  involuntary  resettlement,  or  impacts  on  the 
environment  and  indigenous  peoples  as  a  result  of  the  change.  The  project  will  remain 
classified as environmental category B. Much of the additional work will be in sections through 
barren  areas.  A  sound  environmental  management  plan,  which  adequately  covers  the 
additional work, is currently in place and MOTC reports the environmental quality every month 
to  ADB.  No  adverse  impacts  have  been  reported  to  date,  and  none  are  expected  due  to  the 
proposed  changes.  The  supplement  to  the  initial  environmental  examination  includes  the 
revisions to the environmental management plan and the grievance redress mechanism.16

G. 

Implementation Arrangements 

21.  MOTC,  the  executing  agency  for  the  approved  project,  and  the  project  implementation 
unit (which was renamed the investment project implementation group in June 2010) will remain 
unchanged  and  will  continue  to  manage  the  project.  The  renaming  has  not  changed  its 
structure,  responsibilities,  staff,  or  the  lines  of  communication  with  MOTC.  All  donor-financed 
projects are now under one group with a director in charge of overall operations and a deputy 
director  serving  as  the  focal  person  for  ADB  projects.  The  activities  financed  from  the 
supplementary loan will be implemented over 18 months.  
 
22. 
According  to  the  first procurement  plan  of  the approved  project,  civil  works  were  to  be 
procured as three packages using ADB's international competitive bidding procedure. However, 
early in the procurement process, the government felt that competition for small packages was 
limited. Therefore, during the inception mission, the three were combined into one package, and 
bids  were  called  on  21  March  2008.  ADB's  procurement  committee  agreed  with  MOTC's 
evaluation, and the contract was awarded to the lowest responsive bidder on 6 October 2008 at 
a  price  of  $22.9  million  including  $2  million  for  contingencies. 18 The  contract  price  for  the 
pavement works—5 cm (single) layer of asphalt concrete over 56 km—was $6.1 million.  
 
23.  MOTC  has proposed  procuring  additional  works  through  a variation  of the  original civil 
works contract instead of through new procurement.  It has received an expression of interest 
from the contractor for the additional works and a set of likely unit prices, including prices for the 
two new items—the second layer with a 4% bitumen content and the tack coat between layers. 
The  total  estimated  cost  of  these  works  is  $20.3  million.  However,  supplies  of  imported  road 
construction  materials  and  petroleum  products  from  the  traditional  producers,  particularly 
bitumen  and  diesel,  are  becoming  unreliable  and  costly.  This  is  mainly  because  of  the 
increasing  demand  for  these  materials  in  the  source  countries  and  intermittent  export 
restrictions. The political changes and the civil unrest in the Kyrgyz Republic in April and June 
2010 also contributed to the price escalation, which is expected to continue in the near future. 
The government has found suppliers of road construction materials and petroleum products in 
nonmember  countries  of  ADB.  These  are  reliable  and  offer  lower  prices.  The  total  cost 
represents  a  relatively  small  amount  of  the  supplementary  loan  (around  5%).  To  enable  the 
government to source from the least expensive producers, and thereby maximize the project’s 
development  impact  and  economic  efficiency,  it  is  proposed  that  road  construction  materials 
and  petroleum  products  procured  from  nonmember  countries  of  ADB  be  eligible  for  financing 
under the supplementary loan.

 ADB  has  performed  comparative  analyses  of  the  material  and  time  cost  of  new 
24. 
procurement  versus  contract  variation,  and  found  that  a  variation  would  be  more  economical 
than new procurement.19  The estimated total cost of works, if newly procured, is $26 million20—
about $6.0 million more than the contract variation. The indirect cost of delays, and the practical 
difficulties that a new contractor will face, are also relevant. The earliest a new contractor could 
start  would  be  June  2011  (the  current  contract  ends  on  30  May  2011),  which  would  push  the 
project  completion  date  to  the  end  of  2013  (past  the  current  grant  closing  date).  Moreover, 
transferring the defects liability to a new contractor, and placing the second layer 2 years after 
placing the first layer of asphalt, are impractical. Therefore, MOTC's proposal is fully justified. 
 
25. 
Likewise,  MOTC's  proposal  for  procuring  the  additional  consulting  services  for 
construction  supervision  through  a  contract  variation  is  justified.  The  services  include 
approximately  15  person-months  of  international  consultants'  input  and  60  person-months  of 
national  consultants'  input.  This  method  of  procurement  will  also  be  less  disruptive  to  the 
contractor–consultant  working  relationship.  The  services  of  national  and/or  international 
specialists  to  assist  the  investment  project  implementation  group  with  administering  the 
contracts  and  solving  complex  problems  will  be  engaged  according  to  national  and  ADB's 
procurement procedures for recruitment of individual consultants. The firm engaged to carry out 
annual financial audits will continue its services until the end of the project and any additional 
costs  will  be  covered  from  the  budget  allocation  for  consulting  services.  Under  the  consulting 
services  category,  MOTC  will  also procure  training  and  related  material  such  as manuals  and 
software on project management to build its capacity for in project management.  
 
26. 
ADB  Management  has,  in  principle,  approved  advance  contracting  and  retroactive 
financing from the loan proceeds for expenditures incurred on eligible civil works and consulting 
services.  The  government  was  informed  that  advance  contracting  must  comply  with  ADB’s 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) for expenditures to be eligible for retroactive 
financing.  Once  the  loan  becomes  effective,  up  to  20%  of  the  proceeds  may  be  used  to 
retroactively  finance  eligible  expenditures  incurred  during  the  period  not  exceeding  6  months 
prior to signing of the loan agreement. The government acknowledges that advance contracting 
prior  to  signing  of  the  loan  agreement  is  undertaken  at  its  own  risk.  Concurrence  by  ADB  on 
advance  contracting  does  not  commit  ADB  to  finance  any  expenditures.  ADB’s  Anticorruption 
Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and  discussed  with  the  government  and

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

27. 
The advantages of the proposed change include a longer service life for the road, more 
opportunities to use recycled materials, and ease of overlaying. The resultant higher speeds will 
reduce travel time and vehicle operating costs. An economic analysis was done assuming that 
the  cost  consists  of  (i) capital  expenditure,  including  physical  contingencies;  and  (ii)  operation 
and maintenance expenditure, and the benefit consists of (i) savings in vehicle operating costs, 
and (ii) savings in travel time.  
 
28. 
The  benefit  stems  from  the  estimated  travel  time  savings  because  the  average  travel 
speed  on  the  road  will  increase  from  30  kilometers  per  hour  (km/h)  to  60  km/h  (instead  of  40 
km/h22 with the approved project). Likewise, the estimated operating costs will decline because 
the average pavement roughness index will drop from 15.0 to 3.0 (it will drop to only 6.5 with 
approved project). Moreover, the maintenance cost savings, especially winter maintenance, and 
the  service  life  of  the  pavement  will  be  substantially  higher.  Together,  these  will  yield  a  net 
present  value  of  $318  million  and  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  19%,  compared  with 
18% for the approved project. A sensitivity test has confirmed that, even with a 20% increase in 
capital expenditure and a 20% reduction in operational savings, the return will be 14%.23 
 
29. 
Surfacing will increase access to and from the communities within the corridor because 
public transport and private vehicles will be able to use the road year-round, thereby reducing 
travel time to market, social services, and employment and educational opportunities. Although 
difficult  to  quantify,  health  benefits  are  likely  from  the  substantial  reduction  in  vehicle-induced 
dust  and  noise  from  the  paved  surface  compared  with  the  original  unpaved  surface.  Public 
awareness  campaigns  financed  and  organized  under  the  civil  works  contracts  and  MOTC's 
continued  consultation  with  local  communities  will  help  minimize  the  social  implications  of 
increased traffic. 
 
The  risk  of  cost  overruns  caused  by  large  increases  in  material  and  equipment  costs 
30. 
cited  in  the  report  and  recommendation  of  the  approved  project  (footnote  2)  will  increase 
because of the high value of the material for the new pavement surface. In addition to assuring 
financing, the government will negotiate escalation limits or a guaranteed maximum price with 
the  contractor  to  contain  the  cost  within  the  budget  and  minimize  the  risk  of  cost  overruns. 
MOTC  will  implement  measures  such  bumps  on  the  road,  signs,  and  police  surveillance  to 
reduce the traffic accident risks and noise caused by higher vehicle speeds.  
 

V. 

ASSURANCES 

31. 
The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to 
all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as  described  in  detail  in  the 
project  administration  memorandum  and  legal  documents.  The  government  has  agreed  with 
ADB  on  certain  covenants  for  the  project,  which  are  set  forth  in  the  supplementary  loan 
agreement.

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

32. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  supplementary 
loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR15,189,000 to the Kyrgyz Republic for the CAREC 
Regional  Road  Corridor  Improvement  Project  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources  with  an 
interest  charge  at  the  rate  of  1.0%  per  annum  during  the  grace  period  and  1.5%  per  annum 
thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and 
conditions  as  are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  agreement 
presented to the Board. 
 
33. 
I also recommend that the Board approve the proposal set forth in paragraph 23 of this 
report  that  road  construction  materials  and  petroleum  products  procured  from  nonmember 
countries of ADB be eligible for financing under the supplementary loan. If this recommendation 
is not approved and the Board only approves the recommendations in paragraph 32, then road 
construction  materials  and  petroleum  products  procured  only  from  member  countries  of  ADB 
will be eligible for financing under the supplementary loan.
